div1.p: Griffitts discusses the possible influence of humidity on the mosquito life-span.

div1.head: Letter from T.H.D. Griffitts to Henry Rose Carter, October 22, 1924
div1.opener:
Addresses
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
Griffitts-
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
519 Dexter Ave.
Montgomery, Ala.
Octobere 22, 1924
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I greatly appreciate the letter received yesterday.
I also got your letter of several days ago concern-
ing the Indian Journal Abot. on malaria con-
ditions. Aside from the limiting influence of tempera-
ture in the development of infectivity is it (or may
it ) not be) well to consider, also, the question
of relative humidity. Could we gain something
on this point (a) in rice fields, or adjacent to
rice fields, where malaria is not as bad as
numbers of A.q. would indicate, and (b) in
impounded water areas where it is
generally as bad. If humidity plays a part
only in the longevity of the mosquito and
not in development to infectivity, or nice
vessa, - or both - we might add to our knowledge
of conditions of biology, if not of control.

I should like to have the paper you
are writing, which you spoke of sending
me.

OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE

TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE

I am, indeed, sorry to hear that Miss
Laura is not feeling well. Is she
allowing herself to work too hard? I
know she is very much like her father when
it comes to work. Work doesn't do
so much harm as lack of proper reenca
tion.

The children are getting along fine -
all in (public) school but Martha, the 3 yr. old.
We are still keeping house. Have a
fairly good negro woman. Tried to
get a white, housekeeper, but could
not get a suitable one. Hope to be
able to have my mother, who is
quite young for her age, with us
at least part of the winter. Mary Tom
is past 14 and really is more dependable
in taking care of affairs than her mother
was for some time. The kiddies
are always wanting to know how you
are. M. T., Jack and Janet remember you
very well.
With best wishes to Miss Laura and your noble self,
